did.abstract: The Carol Burnett papers contains press clippings, photographs, scripts, musical arrangements, personal and business correspondence, sound recorded albums, artwork, awards and scrapbooks.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Carol Burnett was born in San Antonio, Texas in 1933 and moved to Los Angeles when she was a child. She attended UCLA as an undergraduate (1951-1954), first as a journalism major before discovering the musical theater department where she excelled. During the 1950s, Burnett was a frequent guest on television variety programs such as The Dinah Shore Show, The Ed Sullivan Show and The Jack Paar Tonight Show. She became a regular cast member on The Gary Moore Show (1959-1962) where she won her first Emmy. Burnett appeared in several television specials in the 1960s such as Calamity Jane (1963), Carol and Company (1963, 1966) and Julie [Andrews] and Carol at Carnegie Hall (1963), before launching her own weekly variety program The Carol Burnett Show (1966-1978). Her other television projects include Friendly Fire (1979), The Tenth Month (1979) and guest appearances on programs such as All My Children (1983-1995), Mad About You (1986-1999) and Law and Order: Special Victims Unit (2009).

Known for her work in television, Burnett has also appeared in stage and film productions. She made her Broadway debut in the musical Once Upon a Mattress (1959) and has starred in numerous stage performances such as Fade Out, Fade In (1964), I Do! I Do! (1973), Same Time, Next Year (1977, 1980) and Moon Over Buffalo (1995). Her film projects include Pete 'n' Tillie (1972), A Wedding (1978), The Four Seasons (1980) and Annie (1982).

Carol Burnett has been honored throughout her career. She is the recipient of several awards and tributes including a Peabody Award (1963), numerous Emmy, Golden Globe and People's Choice awards and was inducted into the Television Hall of Fame in 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Arranged in the following series: Series 1. Motion Picture Projects; Series 2. Stage and Live Performance Projects; Series 3. Television Projects; Series 4. Artwork; Series 5. Awards and Certificates; Series 6. Photographs; Series 7. Press Clippings; Series 8. Scrapbooks.
This collection consists of press clippings, photographs, scripts, musical arrangements, personal and business correspondence, sound recorded albums, artwork, awards and scrapbooks.

The collection is organized into the following series:
Series 1. Motion Picture Projects, 1963-1982. 5 manuscript boxes; 1 flat box
Series 2. Stage and Live Performance Projects, 1952-1999. 17 manuscript boxes; 3 flat boxes
Series 3. Television Projects, 1956-2005. 34 manuscript boxes; 56 flat boxes
Series 4. Artwork (box 6), 1964-2003. 2 flat boxes
Series 5. Awards and Certificates, 1963-2002. 1 manuscript box; 3 legal boxes; 1 flat box
Series 6. Photographs, 1940s-2003. 9 manuscript boxes; 3 flat boxes
Series 7. Press Clippings, 1955-2000s. 11 manuscript boxes
Series 8. Scrapbooks, 1956-1991. 1 manuscript box; 8 flat boxes
Series 9. The Carol Burnett Show (Music). unknown
Series 10. Sound Recordings, 1967-1972. 1 legal box
Series 11. Correspondence/Biographic Material, 1947-1978. 9 manuscript boxes
Series 12. Writings, 1975-2003. 1 manuscript box; 1 flat box
Series 13. Music, 1958, 1965, undated. 1 flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to motion picture projects featuring Carol Burnett such as the feature films "Annie," "The Four Seasons," "Health," "Pete 'n' Tillie" and "A Wedding." Materials included in this series are photographs, scrapbooks, press clippings and film posters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This sub-series includes materials related to the feature film "Annie," co-starring Carol Burnett, Albert Finney, Ann Reinking, Tim Curry and Bernadette Peters. The film was directed by John Houston for Colombia Pictures. Materials include production stills, cast photos and three scrapbooks containing press clippings and press releases.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Stage and Live Performance Projects series consists of materials related to live performances and/or appearances featuring Carol Burnett. Materials include correspondence, photographs, press clippings, scrapbooks, show programs and sound recordings. Projects include "The Carol Burnett Show," "Fade Out, Fade In," "Once Upon a Mattress," "I Do! I Do!" and performances given at the White House in 1962, 1965, 1969, and 1975.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This sub-series includes materials related to Julie Andrews and Carol Burnett's live performance at Carnegie Hall that was also broadcast on television. Andrews and Burnett also performed together at Lincoln Center (1971) and reunited for the 1992 television special "AT &amp; T Presents Julie and Carol: Together Again." Both the Carnegie Hall live performance and "Julie and Carol: Together Again" are also found in Series 3: Television Projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains material related to the original Broadway musical starring Carol Burnett (a role originated by Burnett). Materials include scripts, photographs and recorded albums. "Once Upon a Mattress" was produced and broadcast for television three times--1964, 1972, and 2005. In 1999, Burnett was a Regents' Professor and directed the UCLA Music Department's student production of the musical. Researchers should cross references the title "Once Upon a Mattress" with the other sub-series by the same name and different year, in Series 3: Television Projects and Series 2: Stage and Live Performance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains material related to the UCLA Music Department's student production of "Once Upon a Mattress," directed by Carol Burnett while she was a Regents' Professor at the university. The original Broadway musical starred Carol Burnett in 1959 (a role originated by Burnett). It was produced and broadcast for television three times--1964, 1972, and 2005. This sub-series contains a script, poster and a scrapbook put together by UCLA students of the production for Burnett. Researchers should cross reference the title "Once Upon a Mattress" with the other sub-series of the same name and different date in Series 3: Television Projects and Series 2: Stage and Live Performance Projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Carol Burnett's participation in The Rehearsal Club's live performance in 1955. The Rehearsal Club was a rooming house for young women trying to break into the entertainment industry in New York City in the 1950s; in 1955 they produced a revue to showcase their talents to agents and producers. Material included in this folder: three show programs, payment confirmation for performance space and numerous telegrams with congratulations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains photographs of the 10th Anniversary celebration for the The Sands hotel in Las Vegas. Pictured are Carol Burnett on stage with five men and two women, all unidentified except for Jack Entratter, The Sands' general manager, and possibly Jayne Mansfield; one photograph of Burnett and Entratter. Also included in folder is a thank you letter to Burnett from Al Freeman, Director of Advertising and Promotions, The Sands. Photographs include 5, 11"x14"; 9, 8"x10", b/w.

This televised show is a reunion for Andrews and Burnett who appeared together in two other televised performances at Carnegie Hall(1963)and Lincoln Center (1971). Materials for these earlier specials are listed under individual sub-series in Series 3: Television Projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains material relating to "The Carol Burnett Show" broadcast in 1991 on CBS. Material includes a press kit with press releases and cast photos of Rick Aviles, Chris Barnes, Carol Burnett, Meagen Fay, Roger Kabler, Jann Karam, Richard Kind and Jessica Lundy. The orginal Carol Burnett Show (1966-1978) is entered as its own sub-series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Show press kit: cast photos, Carol Burnett headshots, cast and producer bios, show press releases. Cast photos include: Burnett, Jessica Lundy, Rick Aviles, Richard Kind, Jann Karam, Chris Barnes, Meagan Fay, Roger Kabler.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Contents are arranged in alphabetical order according to record title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This show was produced and broadcast under the same title, but with different guests in three different years: 1963 with Robert Preston; 1966 with Rock Hudson; and 1990-1991 as just "Carol and Company." This sub-series only contains materials pertaining to the 1963 and 1966 broadcasts; there are no materials available for the 1990-1991 production.

scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains material related to the television musical starring Carol Burnett, adapted from the original 1959 Broadway performance (a role originated by Burnett). Materials include programs, photographs and musical arrangements. The show was produced and broadcast for television three times--1964, 1972, and 2005. In 1999, Burnett was a Regents' Professor and directed the UCLA Music Department's student production of the musical. Researchers should also see Series 3: Television Projects and Series 2: Stage and Live Performance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of various awards and certificates honoring Carol Burnett, as well as press clippings and photographs related to such events. Materials include: the People's Choice honoring Carol Burnett as Favorite Female Entertainer of the Year (1976-81); photographs of the Peabody Award (1963); press clippings for Harvard University's Hasty Pudding Award (1969); Emmy Nominations (1994-1995; 2001-2002); and humanitarian/charity awards such as March of Dimes and Hemophilia Foundations.

Star was awarded to Burnett in 1974.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains various correspondence and biographical material related to Carol Burnett including: fan letters, congratulatory telegrams and party invitations, family photographs, junior high school year book, death certificate of her mother Ina Louise [Carlin or Creighton], letters of thanks for her charity work and theater programs for performances not featuring Burnett in the cast.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Joseph Le Conte Jr. High School where Carol Burnett attended. Includes yearbook and newsletter.

scopecontent.p: Contains photograph of Carol Burnett, her mother Ina Louise [Carlin or Creighton], maternal grandmother Mae and sister Christine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes paperwork pertaining to the funeral and cremation services for Ina Louise Carlin, mother of Carol Burnett: memorial service card, social security card, 2 newspaper obituaries, mortuary service receipts, birth certificate. Services were held at Grand View Memorial Park, 1341 Glenwood Road, Glendale 1, CA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains photographs of Carol Burnett and her sister Christine; Richard Chamberlain and [Mae, maternal grandmother of Carol Burnett].

scopecontent.p: Contains fan letters mostly from young people--elementary through high school.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains seven scripted scenes written by Patt Harbaugh and Carol Kruzynski. Actors listed in scripts include Carol Burnett, Tim Conway, Vicki Lawrence, Harvey Korman and Lyle Waggoner.

did.unittitle: Fan letters used by National Enquirer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains fan letters written in 1971 from young people to Carol Burnett that were used for an article in The National Enquirer. Enclosed in folder is letter from National Enquirer writer Jackie Epstein to Ms. R. Whitney, Carol Burnett Show, dated March 5, 1975, thanking her for the use of the letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fan letters to Carol Burnett that all include a poem; written mostly by young people--elementary through high school.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains 1 xerox copy of a photo with Carol Burnett in costume sitting on the lap of audience member. Back of photo is inscribed to Burnett from J.C. Dunlap, M.D, March 31, 1971. Press clipping of the cover of "Liberty" magazine, published January 26, 1946, with illustration of a red headed housewife in cleaning woman apparel; sent by Mrs. Earl Davis.

did.unittitle: Photos of fan drawings of Carol Burnett

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains photos of fan (children) drawings of Carol Burnett that were included in a TV Guide issue. Also includes note from Leslie Raddatz [from TV Guide] to Rick Ingersoll at the Carol Burnett Show regarding deadlines for the article.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains rejected fan letters to Carol Burnett that all include a poem; written mostly by young people--elementary through high school. Original folder had notation "Rejected poems," but no other information or context.

scopecontent.p: Five consecutive clippings of "Long Sam" cartoon by Bob Lubbers featuring a storyline of a character inspired by Carol Burnett. Also enclosed is a letter of appreciation from Lubbers to Burnett.

did.unittitle: Congratulations letters, birth of Carrie Hamilton

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains cards and telegrams congratulating Carol Burnett and Joe Hamilton on the birth of their first daughter together.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains growth chart from Department of Pediatrics, State University of Iowa for Carol Burnett's daughter, Carrie Hamilton, when she was 9 months old.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Telegrams to Carol Burnett congratulating her on a television broadcast. Unclear which program; all the telegrams are sent on the same date, but none of them name a specific show. One telegram from S. Justus McKinley, President of Emerson College announcing that Burnett will be awarded the first annual Lunt-Fontanne Award for Distinguished Achievement in the Performing Arts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains invitation to "Mr and Mrs. Joe Hamilton" to have dinner with Senator and Mrs. Edward Kennedy; event affiliated with "The Friends of Robert Kennedy."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains letter from NBC to Carol Burnett thanking her for a good work experience; letter from Carol Burnett's public relations company Roger & Cowan regarding various items: contacting Hedda Hopper, Army Archerd; starting rehearsals for Jack Benny Show; meeting with Mirisch Co. and Billy Wilder; meeting with Jule Styne regarding Broadway musical The Unfair Sex.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains 3 thank you letters to Carol Burnett for her participation/contribution to charity organizations: The International Guild for Infant Survival (attached script pages for a PSA); The American Humane Association; The Bide-a-Wee Home Association (adopt a pet organization).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.p: Four articles/academic papers written by Robert W. Firestone, The Glendon Association, Los Angeles, CA, on the topic of psychotherapy and family and parental bonds.
